<span key="dfc026f573b54d8d93c7742b15117507"><span offset-key="dfc026f573b54d8d93c7742b15117507:0">Throwing an error when a condition fails is the most fundamental aspect of a test.</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="ef1dc42460fc4ca8a7a08cf6fd98bdba"><span offset-key="ef1dc42460fc4ca8a7a08cf6fd98bdba:0">An assertion library can be as simple as a function which takes a result and returns an object containing a number of different assertions which allows the user to determine how they want to evaluate that result against an expected value.</span></span>

##

<span key="b7888e35269d49c88d185048d9cdff8b"><span offset-key="b7888e35269d49c88d185048d9cdff8b:0">3. Encapsulate and Isolate Tests by building a JavaScript Testing Framework</span></span>

<span key="bdc55bbf6f94460cb167dc5684bb9563"><span offset-key="bdc55bbf6f94460cb167dc5684bb9563:0">03-encapsulate-and-isolate-tests.js</span></span>

1

<span key="b7428c3f2aaf4f1eaac346c7a1b57a3a"><span offset-key="b7428c3f2aaf4f1eaac346c7a1b57a3a:0">$ node 03-encapsulate-and-isolate-tests.js</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="fd62a053da1e40d19cbc1e4616a25817"><span offset-key="fd62a053da1e40d19cbc1e4616a25817:0">Our naive implementation works, but prevents subsequent errors from being thrown. Additionally, the stack trace indicates the issue is at the location where the error was thrown. A better solution would be to allow tests to continue running beyond the failed ones, and indicates which test is revealing and issue.</span></span>

<span key="d4dc378acea247e4a1c969c9989d5347"><span offset-key="d4dc378acea247e4a1c969c9989d5347:0">This can be fixed by creating a function which takes a title, allowing us to name tests, and a callback function which will be responsible for running the actual tests, and making use of a try-catch block so as to prevent thrown errors from stopping further execution.</span></span>

##

<span key="80b18bbfdb2d4626bfb492af5d4ee0ca"><span offset-key="80b18bbfdb2d4626bfb492af5d4ee0ca:0">4. Support Async Tests with JavaScripts Promises through async await</span></span>

<span key="b6d4c9b62f504cf9a993a6489ac74430"><span offset-key="b6d4c9b62f504cf9a993a6489ac74430:0">$ node 04-support-async-tests.js</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="291562f685ce4816b20e266ff6dd2ca8"><span offset-key="291562f685ce4816b20e266ff6dd2ca8:0">In order to allow async tests to be run, we need our </span>`test`<span offset-key="291562f685ce4816b20e266ff6dd2ca8:2"> function to be </span>`async`<span offset-key="291562f685ce4816b20e266ff6dd2ca8:4">, and we need to prepend the callack invocation with </span>`await`<span offset-key="291562f685ce4816b20e266ff6dd2ca8:6">.</span></span>

##

<span key="dbf52314b35a47ce95aecad35a29ee56"><span offset-key="dbf52314b35a47ce95aecad35a29ee56:0">5. Provide Testing Helper Functions as Globals in JavaScript</span></span>

<span key="28cb09b32ecf403eb7b822042d771935"><span offset-key="28cb09b32ecf403eb7b822042d771935:0">05-provide-testing-helpers-as-globals.js</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="2a002b6d1b4444e49790ab9fd579ee7d"><span offset-key="2a002b6d1b4444e49790ab9fd579ee7d:0">Because of the usefulness of test utilities one could extract them into a module and import them everywhere.</span></span>

<span key="182b19c7c5c34c45a2646a52ed6987dd"><span offset-key="182b19c7c5c34c45a2646a52ed6987dd:0">Another strategy, because we're in a test environment and globals are pragmatic in this situation, is to make the helpers available globally.</span></span>

<span key="494b096aa63c45adbe5200f2c3423260"><span offset-key="494b096aa63c45adbe5200f2c3423260:0">The </span>`--require ./[file].js`<span offset-key="494b096aa63c45adbe5200f2c3423260:2"> flag allows files to be required before executing scripts with the </span>`node`<span offset-key="494b096aa63c45adbe5200f2c3423260:4"> command</span></span>

3

<span key="58825fc1633044d1bb0fbc64f851e353"><span class="r-17y197c" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="58825fc1633044d1bb0fbc64f851e353:0"># or</span></span>

4

<span key="0235374cfb40403a8d293b2fa5eecd82"><span offset-key="0235374cfb40403a8d293b2fa5eecd82:0">$ npx jest 01</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b0c92697345e4160821abbe4475c0b9e"><span offset-key="b0c92697345e4160821abbe4475c0b9e:0">We import both </span>`thumb-war`<span offset-key="b0c92697345e4160821abbe4475c0b9e:2"> and </span>`utils`<span offset-key="b0c92697345e4160821abbe4475c0b9e:4">, and mock out </span>`utils.getWinner`<span offset-key="b0c92697345e4160821abbe4475c0b9e:6"> so that we can evaluate other aspects of </span>`thumb-war`<span offset-key="b0c92697345e4160821abbe4475c0b9e:8">. We are making </span>`utils.getWinner`<span offset-key="b0c92697345e4160821abbe4475c0b9e:10"> deterministic, as the randomness of what it usually returns will affect the outcomes of our tests in non-deterministic ways.</span></span>

<span key="0cda62a1207d4f5393a4f0bdf5f9dc95"><span offset-key="0cda62a1207d4f5393a4f0bdf5f9dc95:0">After mocking, one should always clean up so that subsequent tests are not affected by the mock.</span></span>

##

<span key="c50be6a4b3d6487e852dae6d7723f82e"><span offset-key="c50be6a4b3d6487e852dae6d7723f82e:0">2. Ensure Functions are Called Correctly with JavaScript Mocks</span></span>

<span key="3563582ce5fe42c684cca3b374bde39c"><span offset-key="3563582ce5fe42c684cca3b374bde39c:0">02-ensure-functions-are-called-correctly-with-javascript-mocks.test.js</span></span>

1

<span key="80fa6f288d05488faf12a210f07f53ca"><span offset-key="80fa6f288d05488faf12a210f07f53ca:0">$ node 02-ensure-functions-are-called-correctly-with-javascript-mocks.no-framework.js</span></span>

2

<span key="d9384654f0cc4cdea33f06fefa0e33b0"><span offset-key="d9384654f0cc4cdea33f06fefa0e33b0:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="df1e58791ea94f51800584c26409ca0a"><span class="r-17y197c" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="df1e58791ea94f51800584c26409ca0a:0"># or</span></span>

4

<span key="67387af2e6124778b48f8962bbf0918e"><span offset-key="67387af2e6124778b48f8962bbf0918e:0">$ npx jest 02</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f67d1e7984ba426ea13f3fad2b3ffcb8"><span offset-key="f67d1e7984ba426ea13f3fad2b3ffcb8:0">We can create a naive </span>`jest.fn`<span offset-key="f67d1e7984ba426ea13f3fad2b3ffcb8:2"> which takes a mock implementation, and accepts all arguments passed to it.</span></span>

<span key="88efa0bf94a04605b94b16d180169716"><span offset-key="88efa0bf94a04605b94b16d180169716:0">Onto this mock function we can add a </span>`mock`<span offset-key="88efa0bf94a04605b94b16d180169716:2"> object where we can store calls to the mock function.</span></span>

<span key="aa968e0a71ef44a8becb29661f0dccb3"><span offset-key="aa968e0a71ef44a8becb29661f0dccb3:0">This can all be done using </span>`jest.fn`<span offset-key="aa968e0a71ef44a8becb29661f0dccb3:2">.</span></span>

<span key="ac8daa316e694a1681cfc89668450d62"><span offset-key="ac8daa316e694a1681cfc89668450d62:0">Jest allows one to inspect a mocked function using </span>`toHaveBeenCalledWith`<span offset-key="ac8daa316e694a1681cfc89668450d62:2">, </span>`toHaveBeenNthCalledWith`<span offset-key="ac8daa316e694a1681cfc89668450d62:4">, or to inspect </span>`mockFn.mock.calls`<span offset-key="ac8daa316e694a1681cfc89668450d62:6"> to inspect how the function was used for all calls.</span></span>

##

<span key="8835b24d3d4049ef81ecc2cf12019955"><span offset-key="8835b24d3d4049ef81ecc2cf12019955:0">3. Restore the Original Implementation of a Mocked JavaScript Function with jest.spyOn</span></span>

<span key="6c9f279d20f14015851569f870f20b04"><span offset-key="6c9f279d20f14015851569f870f20b04:0">03-restore-original-implementation-of-a-mocked-function.test.js</span></span>

1

<span key="e4bfd484200c42ea810fdfd16d95bfd9"><span offset-key="e4bfd484200c42ea810fdfd16d95bfd9:0">$ npx jest 03</span></span>

2

<span key="d321ca715887446b932b134fe9cf04f7"><span offset-key="d321ca715887446b932b134fe9cf04f7:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="0cb96a672f934cba939a58fa620a5eda"><span class="r-17y197c" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="0cb96a672f934cba939a58fa620a5eda:0"># or</span></span>

4

<span key="1c2567b37774460e86d30a2e75215ac4"><span offset-key="1c2567b37774460e86d30a2e75215ac4:0">$ node 03-restore-original-implementation-of-a-mocked-function.no-framework.js</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="619129866bf446b6bf3fa7d6883a98ba"><span offset-key="619129866bf446b6bf3fa7d6883a98ba:0">An alternative to using jest.fn to replace a function with a mock implementation is to use </span>`jest.spyOn`<span offset-key="619129866bf446b6bf3fa7d6883a98ba:2"> to create a mock implementation. This mitigates us having to store the original function and replace it, as Jest will do the heavy lifting for us.</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="4ab1ef128d1a4350ae5e7e77c118c730"><span offset-key="4ab1ef128d1a4350ae5e7e77c118c730:0">Use </span>`jest.spyOn(myObject, 'myObjectFn')`</span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="f5ce18673561492ea83b45fb763310cd"><span offset-key="f5ce18673561492ea83b45fb763310cd:0">Use </span>`myObject.myObjectFn.mockImplementation(mockFn)`<span offset-key="f5ce18673561492ea83b45fb763310cd:2"> to create a mock implementation of </span>`myObjectFn`</span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="0378e30899c3474cbf455fa6d73db25e"><span offset-key="0378e30899c3474cbf455fa6d73db25e:0">Once done testing the implementation, use </span>`myObject.myObjectFn.mockRestore()`<span offset-key="0378e30899c3474cbf455fa6d73db25e:2"> to replace the mock implementation with the original so that other tests are not affected. </span>`.mockRestore()`<span offset-key="0378e30899c3474cbf455fa6d73db25e:4"> restores the mock implementation to its pre-mocked definition</span></span>

##

<span key="a55d465e7f804cc0b9e0df5397ee7625"><span offset-key="a55d465e7f804cc0b9e0df5397ee7625:0">4. Mock a JavaScript module in a test</span></span>

<span key="5569ec8c5c6341668f664f18135bcccf"><span offset-key="5569ec8c5c6341668f664f18135bcccf:0">04-mock-a-js-module-in-a-test.test.js</span></span>

1

<span key="7aed965fc4704d6e8b51a2e174f160e8"><span offset-key="7aed965fc4704d6e8b51a2e174f160e8:0">$ npx jest 04</span></span>

2

<span key="b54f4c69f7404d908059c6ff4720d061"><span offset-key="b54f4c69f7404d908059c6ff4720d061:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="7dc0064ccb664df29f581e9c484eee8f"><span class="r-17y197c" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="7dc0064ccb664df29f581e9c484eee8f:0"># or</span></span>

4

<span key="0a67f70fdbd641c285ff931d1bb67da5"><span offset-key="0a67f70fdbd641c285ff931d1bb67da5:0">$ node 04-mock-a-js-module-in-a-test.no-framework.js</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="eee3b30552cc43449e7087d68989c114"><span offset-key="eee3b30552cc43449e7087d68989c114:0">Using </span>`jest.spyOn`<span offset-key="eee3b30552cc43449e7087d68989c114:2"> is still a form of monkey-patching. Monkey-patching is great for our own modules, because we're using commonjs's </span>`require`<span offset-key="eee3b30552cc43449e7087d68989c114:4">. When working in an es environment we'll have to mock an entire module, and </span>`jest.mock`<span offset-key="eee3b30552cc43449e7087d68989c114:6"> allows one to do this.</span></span>

<span key="f820532001a340beb5d4bb6e0edbbe58"><span offset-key="f820532001a340beb5d4bb6e0edbbe58:0">When using </span>`jest.mock`<span offset-key="f820532001a340beb5d4bb6e0edbbe58:2"> we can create the mock implementation inside of the mock, and no longer need to use </span>`jest.spyOn`<span offset-key="f820532001a340beb5d4bb6e0edbbe58:4"> and </span>`[fnToMock].mockImplementation`<span offset-key="f820532001a340beb5d4bb6e0edbbe58:6">.</span></span>

<span key="b6cfaab3e0d546089fd30c2cd75c2c14"><span offset-key="b6cfaab3e0d546089fd30c2cd75c2c14:0">Instead of using </span>`mock.mockRestore()`<span offset-key="b6cfaab3e0d546089fd30c2cd75c2c14:2"> to restore the mock implementation, we now use </span>`mock.mockReset()`<span offset-key="b6cfaab3e0d546089fd30c2cd75c2c14:4">. </span>`mock.mockRestore()`<span offset-key="b6cfaab3e0d546089fd30c2cd75c2c14:6"> is only available for mocks created with </span>`jest.spyOn`</span>

<span key="96a482d0a86c46bd86944029e6270b7a">`jest.mock`<span offset-key="96a482d0a86c46bd86944029e6270b7a:1"> can be placed anywhere in the file, and Jest will hoist it to the top of the file.</span></span>

<span key="20e8dfc6f953422a8cdde33b4a640b02"><span offset-key="20e8dfc6f953422a8cdde33b4a640b02:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<span key="0a2a25af00f9476ea492d5d5add01ab9">`jest.mock`<span offset-key="0a2a25af00f9476ea492d5d5add01ab9:1"> takes control of the entire module requiring system. This can be simulated using </span>`require.cache`<span offset-key="0a2a25af00f9476ea492d5d5add01ab9:3">. </span>`require.cache`<span offset-key="0a2a25af00f9476ea492d5d5add01ab9:5"> is an object that has keys for each import, with each key being associated with an object containining information regarding the import.</span></span>

<span key="0376d212b792431490348520a368f111"><span offset-key="0376d212b792431490348520a368f111:0">We use the </span>`exports`<span offset-key="0376d212b792431490348520a368f111:2"> property to create the mock implementation of the module</span></span>

##

<span key="1e5a8dfd5c23405c9e20d9b6cfcb6b37"><span offset-key="1e5a8dfd5c23405c9e20d9b6cfcb6b37:0">5. Make a shared JavaScript mock module</span></span>

<span key="06b8dff9987d4ec9b3a1e550be407b0a"><span offset-key="06b8dff9987d4ec9b3a1e550be407b0a:0">05-make-a-shared-mock-module.test.js</span></span>

1

<span key="3fd17bdca61741518d315fa04e5e586d"><span offset-key="3fd17bdca61741518d315fa04e5e586d:0">$ npx jest 05</span></span>

2

<span key="06d6047cdc7c4263b6cee72031650f60"><span offset-key="06d6047cdc7c4263b6cee72031650f60:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="c4e033f15f104dfa83710bfc8030c51e"><span class="r-17y197c" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="c4e033f15f104dfa83710bfc8030c51e:0"># or</span></span>

4

<span key="9286eda725af44e3ab8e2a1634f4efa0"><span offset-key="9286eda725af44e3ab8e2a1634f4efa0:0">$ node 05-make-a-shared-mock-module.no-framework.js</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9117042d295e4df492d9bfeffaafcc7b"><span offset-key="9117042d295e4df492d9bfeffaafcc7b:0">We can have tests automatically use the mock of a module by adding the mock to a </span>`__mocks__`<span offset-key="9117042d295e4df492d9bfeffaafcc7b:2"> folder. Node modules can be placed in the </span>`root`<span offset-key="9117042d295e4df492d9bfeffaafcc7b:4"> </span>`__mocks__`<span offset-key="9117042d295e4df492d9bfeffaafcc7b:6"> that Jest inspects, by default adjacent to </span>`node_modules`<span offset-key="9117042d295e4df492d9bfeffaafcc7b:8">. For user-defined </span>`modules`<span offset-key="9117042d295e4df492d9bfeffaafcc7b:10"> they can be placed in a </span>`__mocks__`<span offset-key="9117042d295e4df492d9bfeffaafcc7b:12"> folder adjacent to the module. The mock must use the same filename as the mocked module.</span></span>

<span key="f66ca281ae6e42cfa0030209bd8db091"><span offset-key="f66ca281ae6e42cfa0030209bd8db091:0">For user-defined modules, if the test imports the module, then </span>`jest.mock('./path/to/mock')`<span offset-key="f66ca281ae6e42cfa0030209bd8db091:2"> must be added to the test file.</span></span>

<span key="e4f32e052d1a4960acf7cd3a7d6d1ca8"><span offset-key="e4f32e052d1a4960acf7cd3a7d6d1ca8:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<span key="196927c8c831422a902a49a0fa43ae82"><span offset-key="196927c8c831422a902a49a0fa43ae82:0">Similarly to how we simulated what Jest is doing when conrolling module requiring by using </span>`require.cache`<span offset-key="196927c8c831422a902a49a0fa43ae82:2">. We create a file containing the mock, which also uses our </span>`fn`<span offset-key="196927c8c831422a902a49a0fa43ae82:4"> to allow us to evaluate calls. In our test we import our mock, and then retrieve the cached paths for the actual utils and mock utils, rewriting </span>`require.cache`<span offset-key="196927c8c831422a902a49a0fa43ae82:6">'s key for the actual utils with the mocked utils.</span></span>

<span key="6b93b94d13454b25a7a9d9244fd749db"><span offset-key="6b93b94d13454b25a7a9d9244fd749db:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>
